A 'globular cluster' is a spherical collection of stars that orbits a galactic
core as a satellite. Globular clusters are very tightly bound by gravity, which
gives them their spherical shapes and relatively high stellar densities toward
their centers. The name of this category of star cluster is derived from the
Latin globulusâa small sphere. A globular cluster is sometimes known more simply
as a globular.

Globular clusters, which are found in the halo of a galaxy, contain considerably
more stars and are much older than the less dense galactic, or open clusters,
which are found in the disk. Globular clusters are fairly common; there are
about 150 to 158 {{cite web
 | last=Frommert | first=Hartmut | month=August | year=2007
 | url=http://www.seds.org/~spider/spider/MWGC/mwgc.html title=Milky Way
 | Globular Clusters publisher=SEDS | accessdate=2008-02-26 }} currently
 | known globular clusters in the Milky Way, with perhaps 10 to 20 more still
 | undiscovered. {{cite journal author = Ashman, Keith M.;
 | Zepf, Stephen E. year = 1992 title = The formation of globular clusters in
 | merging and interacting galaxies journal = Astrophysical Journal, Part 1
 | volume = 384 | pages = 50â61 bibcode = 1992ApJ...384...50A | doi =
 | 10.1086/170850 }} Large galaxies can have more: Andromeda, for
 | instance, may have as many as 500. {{cite journal author = Barmby, P.;
 | Huchra, J. P. title=M31 Globular Clusters in the Hubble Space Telescope
 | Archive. I. Cluster Detection and Completeleness journal=The Astronomical
 | Journal | year=2001 volume=122 | issue=5 | pages=2458â2468
 | url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/323457 | doi =
 | 10.1086/323457 | bibcode=2001AJ....122.2458B|arxiv = astro-ph/0107401
 | }} Some giant elliptical galaxies, particularly those at the centers of
 | galaxy clusters, such as M87, {{cite journal author=McLaughlin, Dean E. ;
 | Harris, William E.; Hanes, David A. title=The spatial structure of the M87
 | globular cluster system journal=Astrophysical Journal | year=1994 volume=422
 | | issue=2 | pages=486â507 bibcode=1994ApJ...422..486M doi=10.1086/173744
 | }} have as many as 13,000 globular clusters. These globular clusters
 | orbit the galaxy out to large radii, 40 kiloparsecs (approximately 131,000
 | light-years) or more. {{cite journal author = Dauphole, B.; Geffert, M.;
 | Colin, J.; Ducourant, C.; Odenkirchen, M.; Tucholke, H.-J. title=The
 | kinematics of globular clusters, apocentric distances and a halo metallicity
 | gradient journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | year=1996 volume=313 |
 | pages=119â128 bibcode=1996A&A...313..119D last2 = Geffert last3 = Colin last4
 | = Ducourant last5 = Odenkirchen last6 = Tucholke }}

Every galaxy of sufficient mass in the Local Group has an associated group of
globular clusters, and almost every large galaxy surveyed has been found to
possess a system of globular clusters. {{cite journal
 | last = Harris | first = William E. title=Globular cluster systems in galaxies
 | beyond the Local Group journal=Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics
 | year=1991 | volume=29 issue = 1 | pages=543â579 bibcode=1991ARA&A..29..543H
 | doi=10.1146/annurev.aa.29.090191.002551 }} The Sagittarius Dwarf and
 | Canis Major Dwarf galaxies appear to be in the process of donating their
 | associated globular clusters (such as Palomar 12) to the Milky
 | Way. {{cite journal author=Dinescu, D. I.; Majewski, S. R.; Girard, T.
 | M.; Cudworth, K. M. title=The Absolute Proper Motion of Palomar 12: A Case
 | for Tidal Capture from the Sagittarius Dwarf Spheroidal Galaxy journal=The
 | Astronomical Journal | year=2000 volume=120 | issue=4 | pages=1892â1905
 | bibcode=2000astro.ph..6314D doi=10.1086/301552 |arxiv = astro-ph/0006314
 | }} This demonstrates how many of this galaxy's globular clusters might
 | have been acquired in the past.

Although it appears that globular clusters contain some of the first stars to be
produced in the galaxy, their origins and their role in galactic evolution are
still unclear. It does appear clear that globular clusters are significantly
different from dwarf elliptical galaxies and were formed as part of the star
formation of the parent galaxy rather than as a separate galaxy. {{cite journal
 | last=Lotz | first=Jennifer M. coauthors=Miller, Bryan W.; Ferguson, Henry C.
 | title=The Colors of Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy Globular Cluster Systems, Nuclei,
 | and Stellar Halos journal=The Astrophysical Journal year=2004 |
 | month=September | volume=613 issue=1 | pages=262â278 | doi=10.1086/422871 |
 | bibcode=2004ApJ...613..262L|arxiv = astro-ph/0406002 }} However, recent
 | conjectures by astronomers suggest that globular clusters and dwarf
 | spheroidals may not be clearly separate and distinct types of objects. {{Cite journal last = van den Bergh | first = Sidney
 | authorlink = Sidney van den Bergh title = Globular Clusters and Dwarf
 | Spheroidal Galaxies date = November 2007 journal = MNRAS (Letters), in press
 | arxiv=0711.4795 doi = 10.1111/j.1745-3933.2008.00424.x volume = 385 issue = 1
 | pages = L20 bibcode=2008MNRAS.385L..20V}}
